example.label: bkm:Ref336875300
example.translation: ‘So she sits down again. Sitting, she twines grass.’

example.label: ex:1:3
example.translation: ‘He takes that hat of his and then takes three mangoes to give to the boys.’

example.label: ex:1:11
example.translation: ‘Let me hit instead of (i.e. for) you.’

example.label: ex:1:13
example.translation: ‘S/he killed two deer with bow and arrow.’
‘Where did the (several) goats go?’; NOT *‘Where did the goat go?’

example.label: ex:1:26
example.translation: ‘Over there in the village people are making noise dancing lego-lego.’

example.label: ex:1:32
example.translation: ‘A large boat is travelling on the sea.’
‘The lamp is shining for someone / at something.’

example.label: ex:4:1
example.translation: ‘Sir, did you see (lit. meet) my child?’

example.label: ex:4:10
example.translation: ‘I will tell him the way.’ (lit., ‘I will him about his road.’)

example.label: ex:4:41
example.source: pTNG *maL[a], Teiwa (AP) moħoʔ, Kaera (AP) maxa, Klon (AP) məkεʔ, pTim *muka ‘ground, earth’

example.label: ex:4:42
example.source: pTNG *gatata , Blagar (AP) tata, Adang (AP) taʔata, Klon (AP) təkat, Kui (AP) takata, Abui (AP) takata Fataluku (Tim), Oirata (Tim) tata ‘dry’

example.label: ex:4:43
example.source: pTNG *ini, Blagar (AP), Adang (AP) eŋ, Klon (AP), Kui (AP) -en, Abui (AP) -eiŋ, Kamang (AP) ŋ, Fataluku (Tim) ina, Makalero (Tim) ina, Oirata (Tim) ina ‘eye’

example.label: ex:4:45
example.source: pTNG *mundu ‘internal organ’, Oirata (Tim) muʈu ‘inside’, Makalero mutu ‘inside’, Fataluku mucu ‘inside’, Makasae (Tim) mutu ‘in’

example.label: ex:4:46
example.source: pTNG *sasak, Oriata (Tim) asah(a), Makasae (Tim), Fataluku (Tim) asa, Makalero (Tim) hasa ‘leaf’

example.label: ex:4:48
example.source: pTNG *kuma(n,ŋ)[V] (first syllable lost in some cases), Sawila (AP) -maŋ, Oirata (Tim), Fataluku (Tim) mani ‘neck’

example.label: ex:4:49
example.source: pTNG *(mb, m)elak, Blagar (AP) merax, Retta (AP) melak, Kabola (AP) mereʔ, ‘lightning’

example.label: ex:4:53
example.source: pTNG *wani, Adang (AP) ano, Hamap (AP) hano, Kabola (AP) hanado ‘who’

example.label: ex:4:54
example.source: pTNG *pululu ‘fly, flutter’, Blagar (AP) liri, Adang (AP) liliʔ, Klon (AP) liir, Kui (AP) lir, Abui (AP) liʔ, Kamang (AP) lila, pTim *lore ‘to fly’

example.label: ex:4:55
example.source: pTNG *[si]si, *siti, *pisi ‘urine’, Western Pantar (AP) jir, Blagar (AP) ir, Klon (AP) wri, Retta (AP) vil, Sawila (AP) iripiŋ ‘urine’, Makalero irih ‘urinate’, Makasae iri ‘urine’, Oirata (Tim) iri ‘urine, excrement’
Inanwatan ni- ‘eat, drink, smoke’, pTAP *nVa ‘eat, drink’

example.label: ex:4:58
example.source: Comparison of TAP with Western Dani
Western Dani maluk, proto-Alor (but not pAP or pTAP) *makal ‘bitter’
Western Dani nono ‘what’, Adang (AP) ano, Hamap (AP) hano, Kabola (AP) hanado ‘who’
Western Dani o ‘house’, Kui (AP) ow, Klon (AP) əwi
Ekari menii ‘give to him/her/them (irregular)’, pTAP *-(e,i)na ‘to give’
Ekari maki ‘land’, Teiwa (AP) moħoʔ, Kaera (AP) maxa, Klon (AP) məkεʔ, pTim *muka
Ekari owaa ‘house’, Kui (AP) ow, Klon (AP) əwi

example.label: ex:4:60
example.source: Potential cognates between Iha and TAP
Iha nen ‘older brother’, Iha nan ‘older sister’, pAP *nan(a) ‘elder sibling’

example.label: ex:4:61
example.source: Potential cognates between TAP and Baham
Iha: pTAP sound correspondences Baham adoq ‘tree’, pTAP *hada ‘fire, wood’
Baham wawa, cf., Teiwa (AP) wow, Nedebang (AP) wowa, Kaera (AP) wow ‘mango’

example.label: ex:4:62
example.source: Potential cognates between TAP/AP and Karas

example.label: ex:6:1
example.source: Variation in the realization of Kamang (Atoitaa) ‘six’

example.label: ex:6:2
example.source: Variation in the realization of Sawila ‘six’

example.label: ex:6:14
example.translation: ‘... (he) climbed up (and) cut the branch twice...’

example.label: ex:6:16
example.source: Additive operators in ‘eleven’ in the Austronesian languages of eastern Timor

example.label: ex:7:4
example.translation: ‘The pig (that is) over there is still breathing.’

example.label: ex:7:9
example.translation: ‘The tree branch is still over there.’

example.label: ex:7:10
example.translation: ‘The tree branch is still moving over there.’

example.label: ex:7:11
example.translation: ‘He went to this betel (palm) (which is) over here.’

example.label: ex:7:12
example.translation: ‘… (he) again goes to take his thimble to down there.’

example.label: ex:7:14
example.translation: ‘S/he eats fish down there (as you may know).’

example.label: ex:7:15
example.translation: ‘That group of little houses down there is black.’

example.label: ex:7:19
example.translation: ‘My house is as big as the one up there.’

example.label: ex:7:20
example.translation: ‘S/he went up and is up there.’

example.label: ex:7:23
example.translation: ‘There are dogs down there (away from the speaker).’

example.label: ex:7:24
example.translation: ‘The dry stick is standing over there in the forest.’

example.label: ex:7:25
example.translation: ‘There are dogs lying down down there (in a directiondirection away from the speaker).’

example.label: ex:7:28
example.translation: ‘Someone is selling those mangoes on the others mangoes (the upper group of mangoes) over there.’

example.label: ex:7:29
example.translation: ‘That dog up here from the others down there is big.’

example.label: ex:7:30
example.translation: ‘Those who are the ones visible down there will hand over the moko drums.’

example.label: ex:7:31
example.translation: ‘Someone who is up there in a banyan tree sleeping and snoring away.’

example.label: ex:7:34
example.translation: ‘(They) sat on the top of the mountain there and looked down at their village.’

example.label: ex:7:36
example.translation: ‘Apparently, there’s a short (piece of) driftwood caught down there.’

example.label: ex:7:37
example.translation: ‘His wife cradled her child while crying over him going back up there.’

example.label: ex:7:38
example.translation: ‘Somebody was calling him from over there.’

example.label: ex:7:39
example.translation: ‘Markus stumbled on the slope up (which is) up there.’

example.label: bkm:Ref342738939
example.translation: ‘People came in thousands to that place.’

example.label: ex:8:1239
example.translation: ‘If you add three to three, (it’s) six.’

example.label: bkm:Ref358042906
example.translation: ‘Discard two from five then there are three.’

example.label: ex:8:1242
example.translation: ‘If two is subtracted from five, the remainder is three.’

example.label: ex:8:1243
example.translation: ‘If two is taken from five, it is three.’

example.label: bkm:Ref358115306
example.translation: ‘Take two from five thus there are three.’

example.label: bkm:Ref358043144
example.translation: ‘Five on just that four then (it’s) twenty.’

example.label: ex:8:1244
example.translation: ‘Count these four five times and it’s twenty.’

example.label: ex:8:1245
example.translation: ‘If a group of four is counted five times, it is twenty.’

example.label: ex:8:1246
example.translation: ‘Ten divided in two parts (lit. eyes), then (it’s) five.’

example.label: bkm:Ref358116296
example.translation: ‘If a ten is divided into two (you get) a group of five.’

example.label: bkm:Ref342746583
example.translation: ‘a third, a fourth, a tenth’ (lit. ‘Divide into three, four, ten’)

example.label: bkm:Ref342746224
example.translation: ‘half, a third, a fourth/quarter, a tenth’

example.label: bkm:Ref342746258
example.translation: ‘I eat a fourth of the mango.’, ‘I eat the mango in fourths.’

example.label: ex:8:1249
example.translation: ‘One and a half plates of rice’

example.label: ex:8:1250
example.translation: ‘Can I only eat half a mango?’
‘Where did the (several) goats go?’; *‘Where did the goat go?’
‘His friends met him’/‘(He) met his friends.’ (*‘(He) met his friend.’; *‘(They) met their friend.’)

example.label: ex:9:3
example.translation: ‘…, the adults would usually [do it] to make the children and grandchildren sleep…’

example.label: ex:9:4
example.translation: ‘You watch out for my buffaloes and my goats.’

example.label: ex:9:6
example.translation: ‘The chiefs were amazed.’ (*‘The chief is amazed.’)

example.label: ex:9:7
example.translation: ‘A bunch of balls are spread out on the table.’

example.label: ex:9:8
example.translation: ‘Those clean shirts of that man, collect them.’
‘Pour out that little bit of water and get some more from the well.’
Intended: ‘Pour out the two bits of water and get some more from the well.’

example.label: ex:9:15
example.translation: ‘A bunch of balls are spread out on the table.’

example.label: bkm:Ref334530759
example.translation: ‘Three large balls and five small balls are sitting on the table.’

example.label: ex:9:23
example.translation: ‘Were many [rather than few] goats brought here?’

example.label: ex:9:24
example.translation: ‘Pick up the many coconuts.’ [situation: there are many coconuts in a pile of various kinds of fruits, and the order is to pick up these, not the rest]
‘Her children (lit. those her children) have died.’
‘Many of these (known) goats were chopped up.’
‘These (known) goats were chopped up by someone.’
‘the {specific group of} people {not some other group}’

example.label: ex:9:42
example.translation: ‘Those villages make war together (against another village).’

example.label: ex:9:44
example.translation: ‘…, her children and their associates come to mourn.’

example.label: ex:9:45
example.translation: ‘Marten and his associates run away from me.’

example.label: ex:9:47
example.translation: ‘...those people who were inside the car were taken over the [edge of the] cliff.’

example.label: ex:9:48
example.translation: ‘Pluck off [all] the rice that is in the garden [and] take it down to the village.’
‘His children were six.’ i.e., ‘He had six children.’
‘His children were many.’ i.e., ‘He had many children.’

example.label: ex:9:51
example.translation: ‘They went to the mountains to check the garden.’
Benny assoc garden go.to ‘Benny and his associates go to the garden.’
‘Different individuals called Benny go to the garden.’
‘Two or more people called Benny go to the garden.’
near pl lit. ‘the near ones’; i.e. ‘neighbours’
lit. ‘the new ones’; i.e. ‘the newcomers, the Malays’

example.label: ex:9:60
example.translation: ‘All its roots were pulled right up.’

example.label: ex:9:63
example.translation: ‘Peter and the others were afraid to die.’

example.label: ex:9:65
example.translation: ‘We placed our fishponds, placed our fish traps, and then people took all the fish.’

example.label: ex:9:66
example.translation: ‘All the people spread out [to look for them]’ (Lit. ‘All people they were all going spreading ...’)

example.label: ex:9:67
example.translation: Intended: ‘All people they were twenty going spreading...’

example.label: ex:9:69
example.translation: ‘Those birds were everywhere there, swarming over the saliva of his mother.’

example.label: ex:9:70
example.translation: ‘Stow all the corn in the basket.’

example.label: ex:9:71
example.translation: ‘All my mangos got stolen, it really shocked me.’

example.label: ex:9:74
example.translation: ‘...(while) he sat (unexpectedly many) black ants came crawling into his sarong,...’

example.label: ex:9:75
example.translation: ‘When the east wind blows, a mass of rocks and sand from the beach is lifted up and deposited on dry land (beyond the beach).’
‘Benny and his associates go to the garden.’
‘Different individuals called Benny go to the garden.’
‘I fill the drum with several containers of water.’

example.label: ex:9:82
example.translation: ‘Where did that group of Teiwa [people] go to?’

example.label: ex:9:83
example.translation: ‘They think that if they alone make war against the people of Takailubui,...’

example.label: ex:9:84
example.translation: ‘Some of these citrus fruits, others are sour.’

example.label: ex:9:85
example.translation: ‘Some of them went home going up to Molpui, others went straight home going up across to the village.’

example.label: ex:9:87
example.translation: ‘I will teach them Abui and other friends of ours will teach them Pantar and Sawila.’

example.label: ex:9:88
example.translation: ‘You all keep sitting, I’m going to sleep.’

example.label: ex:9:90
example.translation: ‘My (female) friends, let’s get up to eat.’

example.reference: Response to video clip P04wake.up07, SP3
example.label: bkm:Ref383697262
bkm:Ref306280773
example.translation: ‘Sir, did you see (lit. meet) my child?’

example.label: bkm:Ref353455505
example.translation: ‘The dog ran off (was forced to run).’

example.label: ex:10:1236
example.translation: ‘[…] his father comes and wakes him.’

example.reference: Response to video clip C01pullperson25, SP8
example.label: bkm:Ref306280933
bkm:Ref383697342
example.translation: ‘When the younger one followed him, people killed (him).’

example.label: bkm:Ref383697370
example.translation: ‘Has that rat that was in a hole already been stabbed?’

example.label: bkm:Ref383697375
example.translation: ‘There are rats in the hole, so take a stick and run them through!’

example.reference: Response to video clip P20run06, SP8
example.label: bkm:Ref283206980

example.reference: Response to video clip P09person.fall14, SP 9
example.label: bkm:Ref383854029
example.translation: ‘A man walks along and stumbles there, whoops!’ [α-type prefix: do-]

example.reference: Response to video clip P21stand.up02, SP11
example.translation: ‘The guy stands up and leaves.’ [α-type prefix: da-]

example.reference: Response to video clip P21stand.up02, SP12
example.label: bkm:Ref324337569
bkm:Ref372879227
example.translation: ‘Don’t you forget to bring the bananas.’

example.label: ex:10:1239
example.translation: ‘A palm rib burns down/on (i.e., is consumed over time).’

example.label: bkm:Ref384657017
example.translation: ‘The mountains are cold.’ (i.e., ‘In the mountains, it is cold.’)

example.label: bkm:Ref384657025
example.translation: ‘I have cooled.’ (i.e., ‘My fever has come down.’)

example.reference: Response to video clip P07wake.up.person19, SP4
example.label: bkm:Ref283206596
example.translation: ‘An old man comes and wakes up a small child.’

example.label: ex:10:1242
example.translation: ‘[…] You go look for dry bamboo to bring here.’

example.reference: Response to video clip C13bumpintoperson38, SP4
example.label: bkm:Ref306281423
example.translation: ‘A man is going and bumps into an old man.’

example.reference: Response to video clip C16bumpintotree42, SP4
example.label: ex:10:1243
example.translation: ‘An old man walks and bumps into a tree.’

example.reference: Response to video clip C04step.on.person32, SP4
example.label: bkm:Ref383697393
example.translation: ‘A child comes and steps on his father.’

example.reference: Response to video clip C20step.on.banana33, SP4
example.label: bkm:Ref383697402
example.translation: ‘An old man comes and steps on a ripe banana …’

example.reference: Response to video clip P15hold.person24, SP3
example.label: ex:10:1244
example.translation: ‘An old man is standing cradling his child.’
